{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127924,"name":"","username":"crazrRobot123","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crazrrobot123/{size}/211176_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T05:01:52.223Z","cooked":"

Our team has some NEO motors with 15 tooth 32 DP 8mm round bore steel pinion gears installed and we are looking for the best option to remove them without damaging the motor.

Any suggestions?

Thanks.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-01-17T05:01:52.223Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":417,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":2134.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423514,"topic_slug":"remove-pinion-from-neo-motor","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/remove-pinion-from-neo-motor/423514/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3127957,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T07:24:43.198Z","cooked":"

A tool you would be looking for is called a “gear puller” though it’s tricky to find ones the right size for this task. I’m sure somebody else has an amazon link floating around, but I haven’t used that particular solution. An alternative is making something yourself to do that specific job, like this:

image798×768 53.2 KB

My go-to here is just a propane torch. Hold the motor upside down and heat just the gear as evenly as you can; it should slide off after a minute or so. I’ve never had to, but you may need to use a pair of pliers to give it a little yank though there should be very little resistance.
This likely ruins the heat-treatment of the pinion.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-01-17T07:25:04.513Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":219,"readers_count":218,"score":163.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":423514,"topic_slug":"remove-pinion-from-neo-motor","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/a/c/ac1026cc61fff8381cc6d7fb1ba6b4a87c6c4f9c.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/remove-pinion-from-neo-motor/423514/2","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3132195,"name":"Squillo","username":"Squillo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/squillo/{size}/78981_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-23T08:56:04.620Z","cooked":"

I would love it if someone could post a link to the proper size gear puller (to purchase). I have found one that is for “1mm-5mm shafts” but the Neo shaft looks a bit bigger than 5mm. The others on Amazon do not say what size they are, and they all seem to be either too big (for cars) or too small.

We have had no luck with heat.
